name: 2-fluoroquinoline-3-boronic acid
Reason: 2-fluoroquinoline-3-boronic acid has a melting point influenced by its structural components relative to the base of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings and a fluorine atom. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. The fluorine atom introduces a significant increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at approximately +10 degrees Celsius. The two additional phenyl rings can significantly augment the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions and rigidity. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions and rigidity.
